Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted rock art showing nine human and three quadruped animal figures, painted and infilled. The human figures are all upright and range in colour from light to dark brown. At the top left are three small figures in light brown, apparently in motion and pointing right. They appear to be wearing skirts except for that in the centre, which has a long horizontal line in the same pigment extending back from the head. To the lower right of these is a larger figure in darker brown pointing right with legs extended as if seated and the left hand on the hip. To the right of this is the faded stick-figure style figure of an unidentified quadruped in light brown facing left, superimposed by a walking figure facing right. In the centre of the image are two infilled figures facing right. The figure on the left appears to be depicted in a leaping-like motion with arms extended and bent knees. The larger figure on the right has one arm bent behind and the other extended forwards and superimposes a very faded quadruped (cow?) facing right. To the lower left is an unidentified shape, bovid, cattle/caprine - not clear due to superimpositions. To the top right of the image are the figures of two very small human figures in dark pigment facing pointing diagonally up and left and cut off the edge of the image at the waist and to the bottom left is the faded outline of the hindquarters and back legs of a equid-like animal in white, facing right and cut off the edge of the image at the shoulder, and to the right a gazelle. Karkur Talh, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Detail of 2013.2034.29. This site is in the west bank of a blocked wadi which once flowed into the wadi with the waterfall site 2013.2034.1-4. A crude shelter with a rough solid-rock floor about 6m wide and 25m deep; just over 1m high. Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
